div.p:
The
confirmation of the Newspaper
Report of Charles Scotts death
never arrived till last night
- the Persian ministers Messenger
having been stopped by our Ambas
-aderAmbassador at Vienna for a weakweek
. I had no dubtdoubt of the truth of
the sad story - but still cdcould
not write to you as I otherwise
wdwould have benbeen sure to do, in
the absence of direct intelligence

I am very grateful for
all your Kind thoughts and

recollections. Charles has only
joined a Company who are
& ever will be as presntpresent
to me while memory remains
as if they still were partaking
in what we call Life. It
is however a very serious
calamtycalamity to me - for we had
very much in common &
it was to him I had always
looked, in case of my
own death, for protection
of my children during
their tender years or rather

I shd say for giving them
that caste of mind &
sentiments which I wd fain
have them inherit from
their mother.

But no more - we are all
pretty well. I enclose some
letters which you will read
w a tender interest.
After the 19th October he
continued to droop & died
on the 28th of that Month.
without apparent pain -
having so long as conscious
-nessconsciousness continued spoken
tranquilly Even cheerfully

- not indicating to his friends
any apprehension of the near
fate. For friends he had -
Sir John McNiel & the
Physician Dr Bell a Nephew
of Sir Charles were both old
friends of his own as well
as of mine & Whatever cdcould
be done to soothe his pillow
was done by them - & he now
Shares the grave of one of
McNiels own children who
died there some years ago.
div.closer:
Ever affectenalyaffectionately Yours
J G Lockhart
